description: From Old Norse baðask (“to take a bath”, literally “to bathe oneself”), mediopassive form from underlying baða (“to bathe”) + sik (“oneself”), from Proto-Germanic *baþōną and *sek. Doublet of English bathe.

verbs.description: bask (third-person singular simple present basks, present participle basking, simple past and past participle basked)

entries.meaning: To bathe in warmth; to be exposed to pleasant heat.
(figurative) To take great pleasure or satisfaction; to feel warmth or happiness. (This verb is usually followed by "in").
